Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Laconian black-figured pottery kylix; dull cream slip; interior: black-figure decoration consisting of part of snake's head and coils from bodies of snakes; exterior: from top, part of horizontal handle palmette; frieze of short rising rays; frieze of short tongues (one with dot in added red at its centre); friezes separated by groups of narrow and wide black bands with superimposed added red.
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.526.a, 1888,0601.526.e and possibly 1888,0601.526.q. The fragments of the B7.4 cup show a wing and snakes, a combination that makes possible the suggestion that the subject was Typhon, although the work is too fragmentary to allow certain identification. There are some obscure points as well: wings are not a common feature for a sea-daemon. From the little that is left of B7.4, however, a reconstruction is almost impossible, so the question of form and identity must be left open. See Pipili, M., Laconian Iconography of the Sixth Century BC. Oxford 1987, 69. For a wholly preserved example of a "Typhon" see Pipili 1987, 70, fig. 102 (Cerveteri 67658).
